name: Buerger Disease
description: Inflammatory, segmental, thrombotic vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities. Strongly associated with tobacco use. Characterized by distal extremity ischemia in young smokers with normal proximal pulses.

statement.text: Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) is an inflammatory, segmental, thrombotic vasculitis affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities, strongly associated with tobacco use and characterized by distal extremity ischemia in young smokers with normal proximal pulses.
statement.formal: Buerger Disease: Tobacco Use (Required) + Young Smoker + Distal Ischemia + Normal Proximal Pulses + Segmental Thrombosis â†’ Tobacco Cessation = Only Effective Treatment

explanation.intuition: Buerger disease is essentially a tobacco-induced attack on the small blood vessels of the hands and feet. The arteries become inflamed and clot off segment by segment. The only cure is complete tobacco cessation.
explanation.key_insight: Unlike atherosclerosis, Buerger disease preserves the vessel wall architecture and affects DISTAL vessels with NORMAL proximal pulses. If a young smoker has gangrenous toes but palpable popliteal pulses, think Buerger.
explanation.technical_details: Angiography shows 'corkscrew collaterals' and segmental occlusions. The inflammatory infiltrate is polymorphonuclear with giant cells. All forms of tobacco must be stopped - even one cigarette can precipitate an exacerbation.

epidemiology.geography: Higher in Mediterranean, Middle East, Asia
epidemiology.tobacco: Almost universal tobacco use (cigarettes, cigars, chewing)
epidemiology.prevalence: Declining in developed countries due to reduced smoking

pathophysiology.mechanism: Inflammatory thrombosis with preservation of vessel wall architecture

histology.acute: Highly cellular thrombus with PMNs, microabscesses

pathophysiology.vessels: Small and medium arteries AND veins of extremities
pathophysiology.tobacco_role: Trigger for inflammation, cessation arrests disease

clinical_features.typical_patient: Young male smoker with foot pain and gangrene

distinctive_features.normal_proximal_pulses: Radial/ulnar may be present, digitals absent

criteria_shionoya: Upper limb involvement OR phlebitis migrans
Absence of atherosclerotic risk factors (except smoking)
diagnosis.exclusions: Must rule out atherosclerosis, emboli, autoimmune, thrombophilia
diagnosis.laboratory: Normal ESR, CRP, lipids, glucose (no other risk factors)

smoking_cessation.critical: ONLY intervention proven to halt progression
smoking_cessation.complete: Must include all tobacco products, cannabis
smoking_cessation.outcome: Disease arrested with cessation, progresses with continued use

surgical.revascularization: Usually NOT feasible - no suitable targets
surgical.amputation: Often required for gangrene, tissue loss

management.emerging: Stem cell therapy, gene therapy under investigation

prognosis.with_cessation: Disease arrested, amputation avoided in most

clinical_pearls: Young smoker with distal gangrene and normal proximal pulses = Buerger's
Corkscrew collaterals on angiography are pathognomonic
SMOKING CESSATION is the ONLY effective treatment
learning_objectives: Describe the classic clinical presentation of Buerger disease
Identify angiographic findings characteristic of thromboangiitis obliterans
Explain why smoking cessation is the cornerstone of treatment

sources.citation: Olin JW. Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease). N Engl J Med. 2000;343(12):864-869
